text: White: The darker the paint color, the warmer the interior of the dog hut. A black cottage could be too hot for a dog in the summer. This is clearly seen in the measurements of Tim and Jan's experiment, where the inner temperature of the glass at the black cover is approx. 53 °C, while the interior temperature with the white cover is only approx. It is 42°C.

White :: According to the above experiments, bright colors are recommended because they reflect light and external heat, prevent them from penetrating into the swing and increase the indoor temperature. dark colors absorb light and external heat, resulting in a significant increase in temperature inside the swing.

light grey: The paint color may affect the interior temperature of the dog hut, because the experiment has shown: the darker the color, the warmer it is in the dog hut.  In summer, therefore, white appears to be better, as it is warm anyway and a dark paint color creates unbearable temperatures, while in winter, where it is cold, a darker paint color contributes to a pleasantly warm temperature. Therefore, light grey or dark grey seems to me to be a good compromise.
White :: The color white reflects the light and therefore less light energy is converted into heat
The interior of the dog hut is not so heated.

Light grey: The darker the color, the higher the temperature in sunlight. However, unlike the glasses, the dog hut is unlocked, so the temperature inside does not rise so strongly. A metal cover also removes heat quickly and in the short term. Wood stores heat and releases it over a longer period of time.

Light grey: The darker the paint, the warmer the dog hut. Now, of course, the question is how warm it is outside and how warm the dog would like. As a precaution, take a grade in the middle and not any of the extremes.

White :: The color black absorbs the light and heat of the environment and transmits it to the air embedded in the swing, for which they reconcile bright colors that reflect the light and heat, so that the dog has a better comfort.

Close the glass with the black cover on which a thermometer is attached. Make sure that the starting temperature in the glass is 24°C. Place the lamp 5 cm away from the lock and turn on the lamp. Miss the temperature inside the glass after ten minutes and record the temperature as a passage 1. Turn off the lamp and wait until the temperature in the glass has fallen back to the initial temperature. Repeat steps 2 to 5 for passages 2 and 3. Repeat steps 1 to 6 for the dark grey, light grey and white lock. Calculate and record the average air temperature for each shutter color.
